paragraphs.text:
%md

### Exporting Serialized Models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage

This example creates **Oracle Machine Learning** regression and classification models and exports the models in a serialized format so that they can be scored using the **Oracle Machine Learning (OML) Services REST API**. **OML Services** provides REST API endpoints hosted on Oracle Autonomous Database (ADB). These endpoints enable the storing of Machine Learning models along with its metadata and create scoring endpoints for the model. The REST API for **OML Services** supports both **Oracle Machine Learning** models and  **ONNX** format models, and enables cognitive text functionality.

### In this example we demonstrate:
- Creating Oracle Machine Learning regression and classification models in Autonomous Database using the **iris** data
- Using **DBMS_DATA_MINING.EXPORT_SERMODEL** to export the models from the database to a serialized binary BLOB
- Using the **DBMS_CLOUD** package to send the models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage for scoring using the **OML Services REST API**

### Prerequisites:
- An Oracle Cloud Object Storage bucket where you have read and write access
- A Pre-Authenticated Request defined for the Object Storage bucket
- A copy of the **iris.csv** data saved in the Object Storage bucket
- A Pre-Authenticated Request defined for the **iris.csv** data

Copyright (c) 2020 Oracle Corporation                             
###### [The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0](https://oss.oracle.com/licenses/upl/)
---

msg.data:
Exporting Serialized Models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage

This example creates Oracle Machine Learning regression and classification models and exports the models in a serialized format so that they can be scored using the Oracle Machine Learning (OML) Services REST API. OML Services provides REST API endpoints hosted on Oracle Autonomous Database (ADB). These endpoints enable the storing of Machine Learning models along with its metadata and create scoring endpoints for the model. The REST API for OML Services supports both Oracle Machine Learning models and ONNX format models, and enables cognitive text functionality.

In this example we demonstrate:

  • Creating Oracle Machine Learning regression and classification models in Autonomous Database using the iris data
  • Using DBMS_DATA_MINING.EXPORT_SERMODEL to export the models from the database to a serialized binary BLOB
  • Using the DBMS_CLOUD package to send the models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage for scoring using the OML Services REST API

Prerequisites:

  • An Oracle Cloud Object Storage bucket where you have read and write access
  • A Pre-Authenticated Request defined for the Object Storage bucket
  • A copy of the iris.csv data saved in the Object Storage bucket
  • A Pre-Authenticated Request defined for the iris.csv data

Copyright (c) 2020 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Prerequisites

For this example we demonstrate a complete workflow: importing a CSV file to a table from Oracle Cloud Object Storage, building models on the table, serializing the models to an ADB directory, and sending the serialized models to Object Storage where they can be downloaded for scoring with the **OML Services REST API**.

These steps use the **DBMS_CLOUD** procedure and **Oracle Object Storage**, which require a few configuration steps.

msg.data:
Prerequisites

For this example we demonstrate a complete workflow: importing a CSV file to a table from Oracle Cloud Object Storage, building models on the table, serializing the models to an ADB directory, and sending the serialized models to Object Storage where they can be downloaded for scoring with the OML Services REST API.

These steps use the DBMS_CLOUD procedure and Oracle Object Storage, which require a few configuration steps.

paragraphs.text:
%md #### Object Storage We will use Oracle Cloud **Object Storage Buckets** to store our files. Objects stored within buckets are protected, so one must provide identification information stored in a credential object to access them. Hence, both the bucket and it's stored resources need **Pre-Authenticated Requests**, or **PARs**, to enable access to these objects. To use Object Storage, first create a bucket and then upload iris.csv to the bucket. In the Oracle Cloud navigation menu, under **Core Infrastructure**, click **Object Storage**:
Select your comparment, then use the **Create Bucket** button to create your Object Storage Bucket. To upload the iris.csv file to Object Storage, select the **Upload** button and navigate to iris.csv on your local machine, then select **Upload** from the resulting menu. This image shows the iris.csv file residing in Object Storage.
Object Storage buckets and objects are identified with a URI containing the format: https://objectstorage.region.oraclecloud.com/v1/tenantname/bucketname/objectname #### [Creating Buckets in Object Storage](https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/GSG/Tasks/addingbuckets.htm)

msg.data:
Object Storage

We will use Oracle Cloud Object Storage Buckets to store our files. Objects stored within buckets are protected, so one must provide identification information stored in a credential object to access them. Hence, both the bucket and it's stored resources need Pre-Authenticated Requests, or PARs, to enable access to these objects.

To use Object Storage, first create a bucket and then upload iris.csv to the bucket.

In the Oracle Cloud navigation menu, under Core Infrastructure, click Object Storage:

Select your comparment, then use the Create Bucket button to create your Object Storage Bucket.

To upload the iris.csv file to Object Storage, select the Upload button and navigate to iris.csv on your local machine, then select Upload from the resulting menu.

This image shows the iris.csv file residing in Object Storage.

Object Storage buckets and objects are identified with a URI containing the format:

https://objectstorage.region.oraclecloud.com/v1/tenantname/bucketname/objectname

Creating Buckets in Object Storage

paragraphs.text:
%md #### Pre-Authenticated Requests (PAR) When you create a PAR, a unique PAR URL is generated. Users with this URL can access the resources identified in the PAR using the **DBMS_CLOUD** procedure and the standard HTTP tools **cURL** and **wget**. You can define PARs on both buckets and objects. Bucket PARs can be used to write data into a specific bucket, however object PARs can be used both to read and write data. When creating a PAR you need to specify a PAR name, the resource object or bucket, the authorized operations (read, write, read/write) and the PAR expiration date. For our example, we need PARs for our bucket and the iris.csv resource residing in the bucket. The images below show the steps to obtain a PAR that enables writing objects to bucket OMLServices_bucket_test. Click on the kebab icon and select **Create Pre-Authenticated Request**:
Enter a bucket name, select **Bucket** as the target, and choose an expiration date:
To obtain a PAR for object **iris.csv** stored in bucket OMLServices_bucket_test. Click on the kebab icon and select **Create Pre-Authenticated Request**:
Enter an object name, select **Object** as the target, choose Access Type **PERMITS READS TO AND WRITES ON THE OBJECT**, and select an expiration date:
Once the PAR is created, it is displayed. Save the PAR for your records as it will not be displayed again. Here is an example of a read PAR defined on object **iris.csv** stored in the bucket **OMLServices_bucket_test**: https://objectstorage.us-sanjose-1.oraclecloud.com/p/nhso2xoCVmOqwk0UqAdh5_56e4dOqE2bMZSruJ4yoI/n/adwc4pm/b/OMLServices_bucket_test/o/iris.csv Refer to the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure documentation for more information on PARs. #### [Using Pre-Authenticated Requests](https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingpreauthenticatedrequests.htm)

msg.data:
Pre-Authenticated Requests (PAR)

When you create a PAR, a unique PAR URL is generated. Users with this URL can access the resources identified in the PAR using the DBMS_CLOUD procedure
and the standard HTTP tools cURL and wget.

You can define PARs on both buckets and objects. Bucket PARs can be used to write data into a specific bucket, however object PARs can be used both to read and
write data. When creating a PAR you need to specify a PAR name, the resource object or bucket, the authorized operations (read, write, read/write) and the PAR
expiration date.

For our example, we need PARs for our bucket and the iris.csv resource residing in the bucket. The images below show the steps to obtain a PAR that enables
writing objects to bucket OMLServices_bucket_test.

Click on the kebab icon and select Create Pre-Authenticated Request:

Enter a bucket name, select Bucket as the target, and choose an expiration date:

To obtain a PAR for object iris.csv stored in bucket OMLServices_bucket_test. Click on the kebab icon and select
Create Pre-Authenticated Request:

Enter an object name, select Object as the target, choose Access Type PERMITS READS TO AND WRITES ON THE OBJECT,
and select an expiration date:

Once the PAR is created, it is displayed. Save the PAR for your records as it will not be displayed again.

Here is an example of a read PAR defined on object iris.csv stored in the bucket OMLServices_bucket_test:

https://objectstorage.us-sanjose-1.oraclecloud.com/p/nhso2xoCVmOqwk0UqAdh5_56e4dOqE2bMZSruJ4yoI/n/adwc4pm/b/OMLServices_bucket_test/o/iris.csv

Refer to the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure documentation for more information on PARs.

Using Pre-Authenticated Requests

paragraphs.text:
%md

#### DBMS_CLOUD Package

Next, we configure the **DBMS_CLOUD** package to import file **iris.csv** from Oracle Cloud Object Storage into database table **IRIS_TABLE**. 

To interact with other cloud services, the Oracle ADB Cloud service provides the **DBMS_CLOUD** package. This enables the database engine to transfer and store objects between ADB and Oracle’s Object Storage. 

Refer to the ADB User's Guide more information on the **DBMS_CLOUD** procedure.
#### [Oracle Autonomous Data Warehouse Cloud User's Guide](https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-data-warehouse-cloud/user/load-data-cloud.html#GUID-07900054-CB65-490A-AF3C-39EF45505802)

msg.data:
DBMS_CLOUD Package

Next, we configure the DBMS_CLOUD package to import file iris.csv from Oracle Cloud Object Storage into database table IRIS_TABLE.

To interact with other cloud services, the Oracle ADB Cloud service provides the DBMS_CLOUD package. This enables the database engine to transfer and store objects between ADB and Oracle’s Object Storage.

Refer to the ADB User's Guide more information on the DBMS_CLOUD procedure.

Oracle Autonomous Data Warehouse Cloud User's Guide

paragraphs.text:
%md

Create a cloud user credential in ADB to connect to Cloud Storage using the **DBMS_CLOUD.CREATE_CREDENTIAL** procedure. The **CREATE_CREDENTIAL** 
procedure creates a credential into the current schema. The username and password correspond to the OML user account credentials. In this example, we create a 
cloud credential for user ***OMLUSER*** with password ***PASSWORD***.

msg.data:
Create a cloud user credential in ADB to connect to Cloud Storage using the DBMS_CLOUD.CREATE_CREDENTIAL procedure. The CREATE_CREDENTIAL
procedure creates a credential into the current schema. The username and password correspond to the OML user account credentials. In this example, we create a
cloud credential for user OMLUSER with password PASSWORD.

PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.


---------------------------

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Import iris data to a database table

msg.data: Import iris data to a database table

paragraphs.text:
%md

Run **DBMS_CLOUD.COPY_DATA** package to import file **iris.csv** from Oracle Cloud Object Storage into database table **IRIS_TABLE** and pass your 
Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request (PAR) to the ***file_uri_list*** parameter.

msg.data:
Run DBMS_CLOUD.COPY_DATA package to import file iris.csv from Oracle Cloud Object Storage into database table IRIS_TABLE and pass your
Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request (PAR) to the file_uri_list parameter.

paragraphs.text:
%script

CREATE TABLE IRIS_DATA (
    SEPAL_LENGTH    number,
    SEPAL_WIDTH     number,
    PETAL_LENGTH    number,
    PETAL_WIDTH     number,
    SPECIES         varchar2(4000)
);

begin
    DBMS_CLOUD.COPY_DATA (credential_name => 'MY_CLOUD_CRED',	
                          table_name => 'IRIS_DATA',
	                      file_uri_list => 'https://objectstorage.us-sanjose-1.oraclecloud.com/p/nhso2xoCVmOqwk0UqAgrZ53Sdh5_56e4dOqE2bMZSruJ4yoIWqgjfPPgmJhzuheY/n/adwc4pm/b/OMLServices_bucket_test/o/iris.csv',		
	                      format => json_object('type' value 'CSV'));	
end;
/

msg.data:
Table IRIS_DATA created.


---------------------------

PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.


---------------------------

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Export models from the database to local serialized models

msg.data: Export models from the database to local serialized models

paragraphs.text:
%md

Create a procedure **write_serialized_model** to write the model to a serialized BLOB in the data pump directory. Once exported from the database, the 
serialized models will be sent to Oracle Cloud Object Storage for scoring usingthe  **OML Services REST API**.

msg.data:
Create a procedure write_serialized_model to write the model to a serialized BLOB in the data pump directory. Once exported from the database, the
serialized models will be sent to Oracle Cloud Object Storage for scoring usingthe OML Services REST API.

Procedure WRITE_SERIALIZED_MODEL compiled

ADMIN also needs to execute ***GRANT read, write ON DIRECTORY DATA_PUMP_DIR TO OMLUSER;***.

ADMIN also needs to execute GRANT read, write ON DIRECTORY DATA_PUMP_DIR TO OMLUSER;.

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Send the serialized models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage

msg.data: Send the serialized models to Oracle Cloud Object Storage

paragraphs.text:
%md

Write the serialized models from the ADB data pump directory to Cloud Object Storage using the **DBMS_CLOUD.PUT_OBJECT** procedure.

The **PUT_OBJECT** procedure stores an object into a bucket. It is overloaded to provide the ability to read data from a BLOB to or from 
a directory object. In other words, it can be used to move data from the database server to a cloud service. Create a new bucket PAR where 
the serialized model will reside, then pass your Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request to the ***object_uri*** parameter.

msg.data:
Write the serialized models from the ADB data pump directory to Cloud Object Storage using the DBMS_CLOUD.PUT_OBJECT procedure.

The PUT_OBJECT procedure stores an object into a bucket. It is overloaded to provide the ability to read data from a BLOB to or from
a directory object. In other words, it can be used to move data from the database server to a cloud service. Create a new bucket PAR where
the serialized model will reside, then pass your Oracle Cloud pre-authenticated request to the object_uri parameter.

paragraphs.text:
%script

BEGIN
    DBMS_CLOUD.PUT_OBJECT (credential_name => 'MY_CLOUD_CRED',

paragraphs.text:
%md

The serialized models **GLM_MODEL.mod** and **CLASS_MODEL.mod** are now exported from the ADB data pump directory to Cloud Object Storage and may be 
used for scoring using **OML Services**. 

Download the serialized models as Administrator using the Oracle Cloud Object Storage console.  As a non-Administrative user, download the models on your 
local system by using using **wget** or **cURL** commands on the **Pre-Authenticated Requests**.  Alternatively, use the **Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Command 
Line Interface (CLI)** to import the files.

Refer to the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure documentation for information on configuring your environment for the OCI CLI.

#### [Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Required OCIDs and Keys](https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/tools/oci-cli/2.15.0/oci_cli_docs/)

#### [Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Command Line Reference](https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/apisigningkey.htm)
